div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,243 ALEXANDRIA, Wednesday, JULY 19, 1905. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HASELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Orotava" will leave Suez about July 28
R.M.S "Ormuz" will leave Suez about August 11.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said about July 18
R.M.S. “Ortona" will leave Port Said about August 1
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be made within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: Special Reduced Rates During Summer Season,
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,635 tons, leaves about July 20.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about August 3.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about July 26.
S.S. Yorkshire 4,196 tons leaves about August 9.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about July 5 and August 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about July 20.

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Still very hot and damp, though not so severely felt as on Tuesday, which was a "scorcher." A cool breeze sprang up in the evening. Barometer remaining steady.

div.head: THE JAPANESE FLEET.
div.p: Among the most interesting items of tele graphic news that have arrived this morning, is the information that the large majority of the Russian men-of-war sunk at Port Arthur are far less damaged than was anticipated, and will be perfectly serviceable when raised. The Peresvirat, the Bayan, and the Pallada have already been floated. The Varyak and Novik, victims of the combats of Chemulpho and Aniwa, are also in Japanese hands, and the "crowning mercy" of Tsusima gave Admiral Togo four armoured ships to add to his fleet and in some degree replace the lost Hatsuse and Yashima. Meantime two armoured cruisers of a type indistinguishable from battleships have been laid down in Japan and are progressing rapidly. Twenty-five tor pedo boat destroyers, ten torpedo-boats, and several submarines are on the stocks, and the Katori and Kashima, vessels that can fairly be compared with the King Edward VII., will be delivered at the end of the war. Three huge vessels of a new and superlatively power ful type have also been ordered, and there is no question that in a year's time no Pacific squadron, except perhaps that of the United States of America, will compare with the fleet that will fly the Rising Sun.

England has had the good sense to recognise the imminence of this change and to show her complete confidence in her ally by removing her ironclad squadron to European waters. The seven battleships recalled from China are to add to the strength of the European fleets of Great Britain. Four of them will join the Channel, late Home, Squadron, which will soon number 15 battleships, while the other three will increase the Atlantic Fleet, the Mediterranean Fleet, and the commissioned Reserve. In future the Eastern fleet will consist of three groups of cruisers and be based on Hong Kong, Aden, and Sydney.

The action of the British Government clearly shows that the prophecies of certain publicists, that Japan would be embroiled after the war with the English-speaking Powers, are not likely to be fulfilled in our own case. England hands over the control of the China Seas to her ally-that is all. As to the relations of other Powers with the new mistress of the Pacific, we greatly doubt whether any of the Continental States will dream of attempting to compete with Japan in Eastern waters, or of impeding Japan's action in China. As for America, the two countries are at present on friendly terms, but we wonder how soon the Japanese will resent the threatened exclusion of their compatriots from California, Hawaii, and the Philippines. There is the danger point,-if the Australian and American de mocracies insist on excluding Japanese immigrants or throwing restrictions on their immigration which are not applied to the majority of the low-class Europeans who go to the Commonwealth or the Republic, they may some day have to face the yellow world armed, [illegible]kless and terrible. If, on the contrary, they decide on a liberal policy restricting only the immigration of the ignorant, the diseased, and the criminal, and abandon that colour-prejudice which is such an amazing feature in the most advanced modern demo cracies, the peace of the Pacific is assured for half a century to come.
BECK & CO’S PILSENER BEER
BREMEN.
Obtainable from every Respectable Firm In Cairo, Alexandria & the Sudan.
Otherwise apply to
V. J. FLEURENT, Cairo
F. MICALLEF, Sole Agent, 11 Bab Midan, Alexandria

div.head: Sunlight
div.p: A great economiser and saver of time, health, and strength.
Laundry worries went out of woman's life when Sunlight Soap came into it.
It is the purest Soap going.
Soap
It is reported here that the army has actually landed to the north of Vladivostok.
(Reuter.)

After a series of defeats at Saghalien the Russians are making a stand at Mauka, where the topography prevents further retreat north- wards. The shortness of supplies will probably soon oblige them to surrender.
(Reuter.)
Admiral Kamimura's destroyer flotilla is bombarding the Russians at Youkiman.
The large majority of the Russian men-of- war sunk at Port-Arthur are far less damaged than was anticipated. They will be perfectly serviceable when repaired.
(Reuter.)

In reply to China's notification of the 12th inst., Russia says that as the war is between Russia and Japan, peace will be negotiated by Russo-Japanese plenipotentiaries. Nevertheless Russia, who is in relations of friendship with China, recognises that the latter is interested in certain questions which are to be discussed.
(Reuter.)

The Governor ordered a conference of the commercial and industrial societies to break up on the ground that they were discussing politics. The conference ignored the order and passed a resolution approving the Zemstvoist programme for a Constitution.
(Reuter.)
The great Congress of the Zemstvos has begun without the police interfering.
(Reuter.)
The Congress of delegates from the Zemstvos has been opened at the house of Prince Dolgovoukoff.
(Havas.)
Mutinies continue among the sailors of the Baltic, notwithstanding official denials.

Reuter's Agency learns from Fez that the French, British, and Spanish Ministers are now co-operating with a view to obtaining the Sultan's approval to a Conference. M. St. René-Taillandier and Count Tattenbach have exchanged visits, and the personal relations between the two missions are now unstrained.
(Reuter.)
The crisis in Hungary has culminated in the opposition issuing a manifesto to the country urging the people to refuse to pay taxes and to do military service.
(Reuter.)
A FAMILY BALL will be given at the Hotel Villa Margherita San Stefano, on Saturday next, commencing at 9.30 p.m.
PRIZE DISTRIBUTION.-The annual distribu tion of prizes at the German Catholic School at Alexandria will take place on the 25t inst. at 3.30 p.m.
THE PLAGUE.-Yesterday's bulletin reports a fatal case and a recovery at Alexandria, a fresh case and a death in hospital at Daman hour, and one case at Kafr Zayat.
STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in the Esbekieh district of Cairo during the night of Saturday and at daybreak Sunday will be poisoned by the police.
LEON FEHMY ARRESTED.-M. Leon Fehmy, the editor of "La Justice," has been arrested. He is accused of first attempting to blackmail Orphi Pasha and then of assaulting him in his house.
SAN STEFANO CASINO.-We may remind our Alexandria readers of the children's ball which is to take place at the Casino to-morrow, and which promises to be an enjoyable function.
SUEZ CANAL.-9 vessels passed through the Canal on the 17th inst., all of which were British ships. The day's receipts were frs. 249,728.64 making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 4,921,710.95.

QUARANTINE IN TURKEY.-A telegram from Constantinople states that owing to a case of plague having been discovered at Adalia, arrivals from that port are subjected to 48 hours observation and disinfection.

THE GIRGEH SCANDAL.-The appeal of Hassan Bey Wassif, ex-Moudir of Ghirgeh, will be heard by the Court of Cassation on August 1. The appeal has been presented by Omar Bey Loutfi, till lately sub-director of the Khe divial Law School.

CARLTON HOTEL.-We are asked to remove an impression which apparently exists, that the charges at the Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley, are high. We understand that rooms may be had from P.T. 40 upwards, special apart ments being of course charged a higher rate.

SCHOOL OF AGRICULTURE.-Nine candidates who have finished their studies this year at the 'School of Agriculture' have received their diploma. M. Aristidi Angeletto, M. Missak Yakoubian, and Hussein Effendi Wali have won the first three places in the examination.

ALHAMBRA THEATRE.-The French comedy company occupying the boards of the Alhambra are having a successful run. A mixed pro gramme is announced for to-night, and to morrow night the clever artiste M. Stintzy takes his "benefit" with Le Bossu, ou Le Petit Parisien.

ALEXANDRIA MUSEUM.-The hours of the Greco-Roman Museum have been changed as follows: 9. a.m. to noon and 4 to 6 p.m. On Wednesdays the museum is closed all day. The hours of admission to the Pompey's Pillar excavations and Kom-el-Shougafa re main unchanged, i.e., from 9 a.m. till sunset.

BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.-We would draw the attention of manufacturers and mer chants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appointing suitable agents. As no fee is charged for such advice, it is obviously in the interests of all British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered that the annual sub scription is merely the nominal one of £1. The latter payment also includes a copy of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber. Home enquirers can obtain further particulars from our London office, 36, New Broad-street, which acts as agents to the Chamber.

NEW SYSTEM OF ARTESIAN WELL.- Mr. G. N. Perrakis of Alexandria has invented a new system of artesian well superior to any other system, owing to its perfection and power of resistance, being constructed with the best material and capable of increasing instead of decreasing the supply of water. One of the kind was constructed on the estate of Messrs N. and A. Sursock, and has been patented to avoid imitations. Mr. Perrakis has procured special tools for boring and digging earth of any kind, above 2,000 feet. For hitherto uncultivated lands he accepts the value of the work in land. He has a stock of steam engines, mills, ice-making machines, aerated water plant, tambours (Archimedean screws), sakkiehs, weighing-machines, pumps and accessories, etc. Repairs of machinery also undertaken.

div.head: STATUTORY MEETING-OBJECTS AND PROSPECTS OF THE CO.
div.p: The statutory meeting of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, was held yesterday week at Winchester House, Old Broad-street, London, E.C., Mr. Greville Horsley Palmer(chairman of the company) presiding.
The Secretary (Mr. Sydney William Bart man) having read the notice calling the meeting,

The Chairman said: This is, as you are aware, the statutory general meeting, and you have in your hands the accounts up to April 20th which the Act of Parliament says we must present to you. I have really very little to say. These statutory meetings have been provided by the Acts of Parliament, and all sorts of conditions have been made as to what we are to tell you. I suppose they are devised for the protection of share- holders, but, personally, I do not see how a meeting held under these circumstances can be much protection. The accounts before you are made up to April 30th-a date when the company was in an embryo state, when even the payments on allotment were not complete, and when we had not commenced the investment of even the small portion of funds we had in our hands at that time. I sup pose, at any rate, it gives one an opportunity of seeing the shareholders and having a talk to them, and I wish there were more present, but those who are not present will have the opportunity of reading what I have said. You know there were a good many companies of this kind started much about the same time as we did, and many of the chairmen of these companies have thought fit to indulge in rather extravagant prophecies as to the future of their companies, but this is a course which I do not propose to take. I am rather of the opinion of the American writer who said "Never prophesy unless you know." I do not know anything about the future of this company, but what I do know is that the capital of the company was more than fully subscribed by responsible people and our preliminary expenses were ridiculously small, that no promotion money was paid, and that therefore the whole of the capital of the com pany, with trifling reductions, is available for the purpose of the business. In order to obtain that business we have taken the trouble to get the very best advice we possible can. You will, of course, not expect me to go into the details of the business, but I will say that so far the funds of the company have been employed in a very admirable manner. Mr. Lang Anderson, who is one of our prin ciple advisers in Egypt, is a gentleman who is a very successful worker in all matters connect ed with land investment in Egypt, and we rely very much on his advice. We are all striving to work together to obtain the best results possible for the shareholders. The principle we have laid down is that no ivest ment of a large sum should be made without our being consulted on this side, and so far as we have gone there has not been any conflict of opinion as to the desirability of any of the transactions into which we have entered. If we continue to work together as harmoni ously in future as we have hitherto the results cannot fail to be satisfactory to you. I have been told, with what truth I do not know, that we have been blamed in some quarter in Egypt-not on this side-for keeping the control too much in our own hands, and we have been told that we may lose opportunities of picking up advantageous bargains because time would be lost in communicating with London. If that is so, I cannot help it. Directors year by year have more and more responsibilities thrown upon them by Act of Parliament, and we are bound to protect our selves, and in so doing protect you. If your interests suffer from excess of caution you will at any rate not be able to blame us in that respect. Our policy has been deliberately adopted, and we are not inclined to alter it at present, at all events until we see how we are getting on. I may be expected, perhaps, to give you some idea of the nature of our business. The investment of capital in Egypt is mainly connected with agricultural land, and since the British occupation a wave of prosperity has set in, and I see no reason to doubt it will continue. The native population are realising that life and property are now secure, and the hoarding of money, which was so prevalent in the days of former Khedives is being discontinued. Money is being brought out for the improvement and development of the country, and the natives themselves enter very largely into compe tition in the real estate market. This gives facili ty, and will give facility for some time to come, for the profitable employment of capital in all matters connected with land and agriculture. By this I do not mean gambling in real estate, but it will doubtless often be possible to pick up bargains in land and property with a view to reselling. This, however, I trust, will be the exception. Our idea is to employ our money in loans and mortgages and enterprises that will be bringing in immediate returns, and not to lock it up for years in land speculation. That is the general trend of our business and beyond that I am not prepared to go into further details, though if there are questions which any shareholder wishes to ask I shall be pleased to answer. I now move the adoption of the report and accounts.
Sir John Heron Maxwell seconded the resolu tion, and it was carried unanimously.
A special meeting was afterwards held, at which certain modifications of the articles of association to meet the views of the Committee of the Stock Exchange were formally agreed to.
On the motion of Mr. J. Rupert Campball a vote of thanks was passed to the chairman.

div.head: RECLAMATION PROPOSAL.
div.p: Our readers may be interested to hear that a well-known Alexandrian land-owner is about to propose to the Government an undertaking that will add about a million square metres to the amount of land available for building at Alexandria. The idea of filling up a large part of the shallow Anfouchy Bay and a small section of the Eastern harbour, and using the land thus reclaimed from the sea for building purposes, is most suggestive, and should the proposal be entertained by the Government, and finally carried out, we imagine that rents, which are just now ridicul ously high, will be brought down to juster proportions-if the Government only exercises a little care in drawing up the terms of the concession.

The following report, showing the number of feddans of cotton cultivations which have been attacked by the cotton worm and the work which has been done for its destruction during the week ending 15th inst., has been issued by the Ministry of the Interior:-
Ghizeh:-In this province 3,144 feddans, belonging to 1,700 proprietors, have been attacked and have all been cleared of the worm by 3,119 children.
Kalioubieh:-2,879 feddans, belonging to 1,066 proprietors, have been attacked and 3,243 (?) have been cleared by 14, 842 children.
Menoufieh:-3,222 feddans, belonging to 898 proprietors, have been attacked and 2,991 of these have been cleared by 12,674 children.
Gharbieh:-4,839 feddans, belonging to 874 proprietors, have been attacked and 4,443 feddans have been cleared by 6,870 children.
Sarkieh:-1,953 feddans, belonging to 344 proprietors, have been attacked and have all been cleared by 5,859 children.
Behera:-43,589 fedans, belonging to 5,407 proprietors, have been attacked and 31,963 feddans have been cleared by 97,005 children.
Dakahlieh:-9,163 feddans, belonging to 2,392 proprietors, have been attacked and 8,229 feddans have been cleared by 26, 281 children.
Fayoum:-10 feddans, belonging to 2 pro prietors, have been attacked and cleared by 345 children.
Minieh:-3 feddans, belonging to 3 pro prietors, have been attacked and cleared by 361 children.
Beni-Souef:-1 feddan, belonging to 1 pro prietor, has been attacked and cleared.
Damietta:-142 feddans, belonging to 65 pro prietors, have been attacked and have all been cleared by 896 children.

It is noticeable that in certain provinces the number of feddans which have been attacked has decreased whilst in other provinces an increase in numbers is reported, but it is expected that next week's report will show a general diminution

div.head: (FROM OUR TAHTA CORRESPONDENT).
div.p: July is as a rule a criminal month in our province, for the fellah has little work to do, and is, in consequence, on the alert to avenge the misdeeds of others or to commit fresh crimes himself. I understand that eight crimes took place last week in the Tahta district, of which the following was certainly the most curious.

Two sheikhs were teaching some religious subject in a mosque at Tema. They had many hearers. After a while they disputed over the proper interpretation of a passage, had a sharp quarrel, and were only calmed by the efforts of their audience. But this calm was not of long duration, for one of the sheikhs went to his house and returned with a revolver with which he shot his rival as he passed him in the street. The wound was fortunately not mortal and one of the sheikhs is now in gaol, while the other remains in hospital.

On Sunday night the two brothers of a woman who had been three years a widow fell upon her and strangled her in their house at El Tawader village in the Baliana Markaz. It appears that she had a suitor, who was not "a Hawary" i.e., of pure Arab descent, being but a mere fellah. Her brothers refused his affinity and having suspicions concerning the relations of their sister with her suitor trangled her in the night. Both have been arrested.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Dundee, from Glasgow, Gibraltar, and Malta, with general cargo and coals, left the latter port Wednesday and is due at Alexandria Sunday morning.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Senegal arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria at 10 p.m. on Tuesday.

Main line expresses stop. Fine woods, Sands, Sea bathing mild climate, English Pension, Villa Shelly. Ever home comfort. Electric light. Modern sanitation, Sunny aspect, close to sea and gardens.

div.head: ENGLISH "PERSECUTION"
div.p: The "Neue Preussiche Kreuz Zeitung" is by no means pleased with the tone of the questions asked in Parliament re the formation of a German steamer service on the Nile. Our contemporary writes:-Wherever German trade and German shipping appear in the world's market they are assailed and persecuted by the English. The news that a German S.S. Company was about to start a Nile service drove Lord Muskerry to ask the Government if the report was really true. It almost seems that the people in England regard Egypt as an integral part of the British Empire, though the country is in reality a tributary State of the Ottoman Empire. It was emphatically stated in that much quoted Anglo-French Agreement of April 8, 1904, that, as in Morocco, no political changes should be made in Egypt. The annexation of Egypt by England is therefore forbidden. The Capitulations remain in force and the "most-favored nation" clause operates in the country's commercial relations. On account of this clause no opposition can be made to the appearance of a German shipping company on the scene and to its starting a river service on the Nile, however bitterly the English may discuss the matter.

A Government notice of the 11 inst. includes Alexandria in the list of "infected places," against which quarantine measures are applied. Vessels from infected places not having on board an actual case of cholera, yellow fever or plague, when arriving within 10 days from date of departure, are allowed to load in quaran tine. Vessels from infected places will be admitted to pratique after 10 days from date of departure.

Several complaints have reached us with regard to the promiscuous unloading of boats along the Mahmoudieh Canal in defiance of the regulations, which only permit the un loading of boats, barges, etc., at certain special points near the Gabbari bridge.

A correspondent writes:-A few days ago a boat unloaded in this way near the Serai Sofia, about theree minutes' walk from the tram terminus at Moharrem Bey. A whole cargo of earth was landed, which produced an immense amount of dust, almost blinding the passers-by and annoying residents of houses in the locality. Some of the house-owners of the neighborhood complained at the caracol at Moharrem Bey, but in spite of the orders of the moawen nothing was done to prevent this breach of the regulations. The policemen start ed on his errand but did nothing. Naturally the boatmen were encouraged by their freedom from interference and yesterday another boat began to unload a cargo of straw at the same place. So many people use the canal road on the banks of the Mahmoudieh as a prome nade that the Alexandrian public, which deserves some consideration, counts on the effective aid of the police in putting a stop to this nuisance.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: During the absence of Mrt. Clowes, Mr. Verschoyle will act as Inspector-General of Irrigation for Upper Egypt
Mr. Kenneth Speir, of the Midland Railway, has been apointed Secretary to the President of the Egyptian State Railways.

Our London Correspondent sends us by mail further particulars of the reception held at 22 Charles-street, Berkeley-Square, by Mr. and Mrs. Royle on Wednesday last, on the occasion of the marriage of their daughter to Captain C.W. Maclean. The house was a mass of roses and white flowers, which were chosen for the decoration of the stairs and reception rooms, a most happy combination. There were present Lady Wingate, wife of the Sirdar, wearing a heliotrope toque with a smart dress, and Lady Rogers in pale blue, with lovely lace. Lady Llangattock was in a beige-colored lace gown and toque with touches of blue. Lady Palmer was very smart in mauve chiffon and lace, with picture hat of the same colour. Lady Gorst, in a white dress, wore a China blue hat, and osprey. Miss Gorst was in light silk, with a brown hat, and Mrs. Hunter relieved her black dress by a rose pink hat. Baroness Malortie was dressed in ivory silk and lace, with a little hyacinth toque, and Mrs. Cecil Snow, with a grey gown, wore a heliotrope hat. Mrs. Douglas Morice was in a pale violet dress with a lace hat trimmed with violet ribbon and flowers.

Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said, are Fouad Gress Bey, S. Soubhani Bey, DR. W.N. Aders, Mr. E. Carcassoli, Mr. A. Ronzoni, Mr. and Mrs. Moss, Miss Moss, Mr. J. Cavaiy, Mr. and Mrs. J. Caref, Mrs. Broadbent, Mr. L. Maison, Mr. C. W. Hemp, Mr. J. H. P. Kyan, Mr. D. Macdon ald, Mr. and Mrs. Hood, Mr. O. Bennati, Mr. R. H. Frost, Mr. W. M. Davey, Mr. R. Steele, Mr. Y. Yokos, Mrs. Cornish, Miss McCaul, Mr. W. J. Payne, Mr. M.G. Boyes, Mr. and Mrs. Busby, Lieut. J. Danby, Mr. H. Hanen sen, Mr. Riffari, Mr. Lambert, Mr. Chasse, Mr. H. Meinke, Mr. E. J. Taylor, N.N. Tabet, Mr. H.J.B. Carpenter, Mr. Thos. J. Gatt, Mr. and Mrs. J. C. Devenish, Mr. C. Adda, Aly Bey Baghal, Dr. and Mrs. J.S. Purdy, Mr. and Mrs. Freeman.

div.head: BRITISH BATTLESHIP TOWED.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
div.p: Confirming my telegram of this morning, I learn that the battleship Vengeance, one of the four which have been here since Sunday night, has something seriously wrong with her machinery, which defect made it necessary for the Albion to tow her a considerable distance in the Malacca Straits. She is to leave at 2 p.m. in company with the Ocean, Cen turion, and Albion, and arrangements have been made by the Ocean to tow her as far as Malta, where necessary repairs will be effected.

div.head: CAPTAIN LEITGEB'S DEATH.
div.p: The death of Captain Leitgeb, the much respected agent of the Austrian Lloyd here, has plunged the town in mourning. All flags were half-mast yesterday and but little was talked of beyond the death of this gentleman. Capt. LEitgeb served some 15 years at sea in the Austrian Lloyd vessels, and has represented his company here for many years.

div.head: THE TALE OF THE S.S. CALCHAS
div.p: The Holt Line S.S. Calchas, which came out of the Canal at 10 a.m. to-day, is now on her first homeward voyage after her capture, some five months ago, by the Russians. It appears that she was nearing the end of her voyage outwards, her destination being Yoko hama, and had a certain quantity of cotton and mails on board, both of which had been declared absolute contraband. The vessel,m with the same captain on board as now com mands the ship, was taken to Vladivostock and there guarded with a prize crew over four months in practically the depth of winter. Her entire crew were kept by her under a Russian guard, which treated them in many ways by no means well. The cold was intense, but none of the ship's people appear to have suffered or to have been any the worse for their long stay. The Court at Vladivostok decided that the vessel was a legal prize and intended confiscating her, but eventually merely removed all her contraband and allow ed her to proceed to China, from which coun try she brings the first of the season's teas. She will leave at 4 p.m.

div.head: GOVERNMENT HOSPITAL.
div.p: I have it on good authority that the Egyp tian Hospital, until now managed by a staff of male nurses and Sisters of Mercy, is to have in the near future a matron and four English nurses permanently attached to the institution, in much the same manner as obtains at the British Hospital here now. The hospital has been much improved and is to-day one of the best in the country

div.head: ARRIVAL OF SALVAGE VESSEL.
div.p: On the 15th inst., a tug-boat called the Flamant, towing the Champenois, a 300-ton lighter, caused some little surprise by coming in from sea and anchoring in the port. It was at first supposed that the lighter was towed here for ordinary commercial purposes, but I learn now that the Flamant and her consort are here as the result of consider able thought on the part of a private firm, and that they are intended for salvage work. It will surprise many to learn that not a single properly equipped salvage vessel is owned by the Canal Company and that in almost every case of need of late years, outside aid has been required to salve badly damaged ships, ignoring the cases of ships merely aground.

div.head: ARRIVALS.
div.p: Per P. & O. S.S. Victoria arrived at Port Said on Tuesday from Marseilles-Mr. Mi chaelides, Mr. W. P. G. Graham, Rey. R. Wormell, Mr. J. C. Boyle, Mr. W. H. Halsall, Mr. and Mrs. Huri
Per P. & O. S.S. Osiris, arrived yesterday at Port Said from Brindisi:-Mr. Ahlfeld, Mr. Max Sehiedig, Mr. Mackenzie, Mr. Christian, Mr. Dunkerton.

div.head: DEPARTURES.
div.p: Le paquebot "El Kahira" de la Khedivial Mail parti hier pour le Pirée et Constantinople avait à bord:

LL.EE. Ismaïl Bey Sadik, Neghib Bey Hussein, Osman Bey, Hary Bey, Aly Bey Ramay, M. et Mme Constantin Angelopoulo, M. et Mme Papayoannou, M. et Mme Draco poulos et famille, M. Nicolas G. Ebed et fa mille, M. et Mme Const. Ducarellis et famille, Mme Vve Romanos et famille, Dr. et Mme Phonimos et famille, M. et Mme F.W. Bed dison et famille, Mme et Mlle S. Venios, M. et Mlle A. Catsaros, Mme L. Volteris et famille, MM. Dimos, N. Zoulia, Jean Malolidis, Mohd. Effendi Miliki, William Gross, Jean Yoaunou, C. Clessis, Dimitri S. Canalas, Jean Kauhau sen, M. Chelmi Paul Hermel, Josef Hecht, M. A. Mango, C. Doresa, Const. G. Anastassiadis, O. Diradour, Michel Vafiadis et fils, M. et Mme Thos. Stavros et famille, Mme Const. Coromili et famille, M. et Mme Jean Kefalas et famille, Alexandre Foschini, Ahmend Hamdy, F.M.H. Baxamuss, M. Ilfat, Georges Tzibukis, Const. Arbanitopoulo, Nathan Beja, Antonio et Em manuel Michelis, Aslan Misraki, Nicoles Verghis, Abdein Hassan, S. Valanchis, C. Boucouranas, N. Kistolis, B. Vermont, M. Em manuel, Mmes S. Varanopoulo et famille, Caliope Chronis, Adela Haoem, Caralli, Xenes, Efterpe Pangalos, Catina Emmanuel, Sexandea, Voltura, A. Morou, 6 gouvern 12 bonnes ainsi que 174 passagers de point.

The sharp break in South Africans and the general weakness at the end of last week have been followed by an almost equally quick reaction. The settlement, which concluded yesterday, having gone through practically without a hitch, has helped largely to restore confidence to markets, as well as a report in Paris that a very strong combination is being formed by the greater groups, Messrs. Wernher, Beit, Eckstein, L. Hirsch & Co., Neumann, and the Central Mining Trust, with a view to defeating the market tactics of the Barnato group, and also with the possible end in view of buying up the Barnato interests, who, it is beliefved, would not be altogether averse to withdrawing from Citiy finance at the present juncture.

The appointment of M. Witte as the Russian representative at Washington is taken as a marked step in the direction of peace, negotia tions for which look like being commenced next month in earnest. The success of the new Japanese 4 1/2% loan, taken in conjunction with the admitted failure to raise a small internal loan in Russia, must also help towards an early conclusion of the war.

The gilt-edged market is a decidedly good one, and the present moment should offer good opportunities to the genuine investor. Public interest in the mining section is far too small yet for any marked improvement to be pro bable. The market is too much in the hands of outside manipulators, and, in addition to this, many dealers have had to be helped of late, which must constitute a certain source of weakness.

There has been a rally in the Egyptian min ing section this week, where some well-informed buying has been seen. Nile Valleys certainly look a tempting lock-up at 1 1/8, and United Africans at 1 5/16. A feature yesterday was the rise in Egyptian Mines to 15s. Land Bank shares are steady. Agricultural Banks keep very firm at 13 7/8 on the issue of 243,000 new shares to the present holders share for share at par-£5-which constiutes a very hand some bonus. Nationals are steady at 26 3/8, other shares showing little or no change in price.
In Egyptian cotton the business has been very limited, the higher ptrices having quite checked the demand. Quotations remain without change.
In Futures a moderate business has been done, and the following are the latest values

American Futures. The Market this week has been exceedingly active, and prices have been subject to frequent and violent fluc tuations. To-day's closing values are 27 to 30 points below the highest rates touched. The extreme advance was due to renewed bad weather conditions, and heavy manipulation, chiefly in the American markets, but also to some extent here; the subsequent decline, to improved weather report, to heavy reali sations, and to the growing impression that the disastrous state of the crop has been much exaggerated. The trade here, and in America, has been seriously and adversely affected by the suddenness and magnitude of the late advance, and spinners are now purchasing their minimum requirements. We cannot venture any opinion. All the markets are in a feverish and dangerous state, and it will evidently require regular and favora ble weather conditions to hold speculation in check.
The following are the closing quotations:-
Players beat Gentlemen by 128 runs. The rest of the matches for this date have been drawn.
(Reuter.)

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.
REGATTA.
div.p: The following is the result of yesterday's regatta:-

The wind was fresh from the N.N.W. The handicap was capital in Class I., when 6 boats came in within two minutes, the Sane-Pareille being the straggler. In Class II. the boats were very much divided, the St. George being not at all up to her usual form
